title: Flashing Lights and Floaters (Acute)
disclaimer: Acute onset flashing lights and floaters should undergo a dilated fundus examination[cite: 683].
Perform slit lamp examination to see anterior vitreous; check retina with scleral depression or contact biomicroscopy (3 mirror)[cite: 688].

q1.text: Is there blood, cells or pigment in the vitreous? [cite: 689]

o_discharge.title: Reassure and Discharge [cite: 690]
bullets: Examine to confirm a flat retina and no other ocular pathology[cite: 690].

q2.text: What type of cells/debris are present? [cite: 692, 693, 696]

o_vh.title: Vitreous Haemorrhage [cite: 694]
bullets: Explore for systemic abnormality e.g. diabetes and treat accordingly[cite: 694].

o_vitritis.title: Vitritis [cite: 696]
bullets: Any other associated inflammatory sign in retina present - refer to specialist[cite: 698].

q3.text: Look for a PVD/Weiss ring. What is the finding? [cite: 697]

answers.label: Mild VH with peripheral retina seen and no retinal tear found
Dense VH with no retinal view

o_mild_vh.title: Mild Vitreous Haemorrhage [cite: 703]
bullets: Observe with RD warning signs and close follow up[cite: 704].

o_dense_vh.title: Dense Vitreous Haemorrhage [cite: 705]
bullets: Urgent referral to VR team for early vitrectomy[cite: 707].

o_tear.title: Retinal Tear [cite: 708]
bullets: Review in an appropriate clinic in a 1-2 weeks time[cite: 710].

q5.text: Urgent VR referral required. Is the macula on or off? [cite: 712, 713, 714]
